messages.content: Let's imagine we have a merkle tree root that we keep in the chain and let's call it treeRoot. Users need to update this treeRoot simultaneously by performing operations on the network. Meanwhile, the server keeps track of these updates and adds leaves to the merkle tree. The user who will make a new transaction from the updated merkle tree is provided with witness. For example, user a receives the witness from the server, performs an operation on the network, dispatches the reducer, then publishes an event, the server catches this event and updates the merkle tree and another user repeats the same operations. My question is that when 10 users process at the same time, all of them will get the current state of the merkle tree from the server and process it on the network, but this is incorrect because when the reducer is processed, the new root created by the first of these 10 people will not match the old witness value of the 2nd person. How do you fix this problem? What is the way to process simultaneous transactions?

**the scenario that should have happened:**

user a receives the witness from the server
does the job on the network
event emits
server catches this event and updates the merkle tree

user b gets the most recent witness and the same process is applied

**but the possible scenario:**

user a and user b receive the witness from the server at the same time, causing confusion in the reducer

If you use actions and reducer, then all the actions are processed by one thread, in order, so it's not a problem.  The problem you're describing is the reason they implemented the actions and reducer.  But the same problem is also why teams are building L2s like protokit and zeko as well.  You identify a legitimate issue and there's not a simple solution.

Check out this other thread for some really cool discussion on the cutting edge: https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1200733563297988638/1206632976784425061

when processing actions with reducer, the calculated root of each witness should be equal to the previous one, but if 2 users receive the witness at the same time and dispatch it on the network, the 2nd user's action will be invalid.

That would be a poor implementation of actions.  The action should not rely on chain state.  E.g. the canonical example is an `Add` contract where the number is stored on state and each action adds some number.

In that case, the action shouldn't depend on the existing state of the number.  It just says "whatever the number is, add this value".  State is checked before and after the reducer runs (you as the developer have to implement the logic), so the network state is recursively proved, just not in the state of the action.

with actions and reducers, it should look something like this.

users submits txn with the data they want to add to the tree in the action
the server calls the reducer which calculates the new tree root and proves all the actions have been accounted for, and updates the root onchain.
The users don't need to deal with any witness.

The network status is already changed after the action is completed, let me explain the control done inside as follows:

user a receives the witness and dispatches it. The merkle tree is updated on the server.
user b receives witness and dispatches it 

In the network, the reducer is run and the root generated with the new value of the witness a dispatches is calculated and passed to the next stage. Since the old value of b's witness is updated on the server tree with the new value of a, the old value of b in b's witness must be the same as the root of a's new value.
How do I calculate the new root without witness?

One possibility is that user A submits an action with a new leaf and an index and user B submits an action with a new leaf and an index.  The reducer service would need access to the source data in order to generate each witness, but then it could set the leaf at both indexes.
By the way, a merkle witness for a large tree (e.g. a merkle map) is too big to store in an action anyways.  So the idea of passing a witness in the action is a little bit shaky.
Yes, that's right. So how should I do it?
> One possibility is that user A submits an action with a new leaf and an index and user B submits an action with a new leaf and an index.
A leaf and an index should be 2 Fields, so that's fine to emit as an action
OK, I understand this part, but when I process actions, I need to create a new root with this sent leaf using witness, how do I provide this witness?

I know we advertise it a lot, but if all of that seems like too much work to implement yourself, we created protokit to abstract all those things away and leave only the implementation of your business logic to you. With protokit, you will never have to worry about actions / reducers, not about merkle trees, etc. With the use of something that we call "sequence state mempool", protokit in essence is just a more powerful and developer-friendly reducer API. But there are a lot of other features that you can use.
Check out the docs, we explain a lot of the Mina-related concepts there too: <https://deploy-preview-1--aesthetic-beijinho-ea3a52.netlify.app/docs/tutorials>

I don’t want to be too prescriptive.  Like I said before, there’s not a simple solution.  You could pass the merkle tree as an argument to reduce, you could try using protokit, you could try writing your own custom reducer architecture…
You would provide merkle witness as a private input for each action that you want to process.
@Alsond5 this is how we dealt with the actions reducing complexity, by designing Protokit
yes I watched the video and basically understood it, but I want to develop a method on o1js for my own application by fully understanding what is under the hat.

One thing I want to know here is that I know there is a limitation when using actions, but is there a limitation when dispatching or is there a limitation when processing these actions. For example, can an infinite number of dispatches be run until I process the actions?
yes, but when settling the processed actions you must process all actions to meet the historical sequence state precondition which is up to 5 blocks old sequence state
so if users are dispatching actions for 1000 blocks, you must process actions from at least 995+ blocks
I'm thinking of processing one in each block
but I'll process them in off chain
you can't (shouldnt) control how many actions are dispatched per block, there are some rational limits such as L1 block space
No, I will not control how many actions per block. I will update the network by processing one action per block, no matter how many there are.
per l1 block?
you must process all actions from currentBlockHeight-5, otherwise you wont be able to settle

block 100 -> 500 action came
block 101 -> process all actions + 550 more actions in this block
block 102 -> process all actions ...
I mean doing it this way
have fun ;D there’s a bunch of edge cases to discover along the way
is this method wrong I was thinking to process it in off chain with recursion and prove it on the network 😅
what if you cant prove it in the timespan of 1 L1 block? (3minutes)
to do this effectively you’ll have to reimplement protokit
by the way is the protocol not compatible with node 20 version. I get an error when running the project
Yeah, I hadn't thought about that.
which protocol?
Oh, I'm sorry, I meant protokit.
currently we use some node options that have been deprecated in newer node versions, use ‘nvm use’ in the starter kit to get the compatible node version
so why am I getting these errors I am using wsl
try the following first please: https://deploy-preview-1--aesthetic-beijinho-ea3a52.netlify.app/docs/quickstart

embeds.title: Protokit
embeds.description: Protokit enables developers to build zero-knowledge, interoperable and privacy preserving application chains with a minimal learning curve.

messages.content: i’m not familiar with wsl, not sure its necessary, should run on your linux machine just fine
`pnpm install`?
I already did it
i also used wsl before for doing o1js stuff, it also sometimes had troubles with the paths
@maht0rz Are 8 states allowed in the protokit again?
8 states? no, you can have as much state as you want!
really incredible 😄
its just merkle trees lol
Yeah, I know. I meant the framework itself is incredible 😄

@maht0rz when does the sequencer send the transactions accumulated in l2 to the mina network and is there any way for the user who transacts on the l2 network to send the l1 mina token to the sequencer since the sequencer covers the transaction fee?
when you decide to settle, topmost arrow, bridging of tokens is done via the built in l1/l2 messaging / bridge
Also, when writing methods in protokit, can we write code as we want? For example, like using if or things that are not allowed in mina
you can only write things that work in a circuit - same as in a zk program
the only thing that changes is to use assert instead of assertEquals right
thank you for your understanding, I'm just trying to understand it because it interests me and I want to use it in my project
yep, since in our framework you can prove that something executed incorrectly
if you use assertEquals the proof will "blow up" and you wont be able to prove "incorrect" execution, so we use soft failures
Well, I remember in the video you said that balances data is kept in memory. Won't it be difficult to keep this data as the data grows?
thats just a unit testing implementation, we have a normal database "module" as well
And is it in use? will the process be automated in the same way
yep, there’s an open PR and you’ll be able to use it pretty soon as part of the starter kit setup, and our upcoming testnet integrations
which process?
For example, I will make this.balances.set and it will be automatically saved in the database
that already happens, its an integral part of the framework, you can then also fetch the values via gql apis
not sure what exactly you mean by that question, apps built with Protokit are in close alignment with the MINA L1
I realize I'm asking a lot of questions, but how do we make the address hold an array with the statemap?

Reason for Protokit to exist is to take advantage of the tools MINA offers, including sequence state (actions) and the recursive proof toolkit. The AU protocol is suitable for its own kind of applications, where as Protokit can power various other, possibly way more complex use cases such as app chains
you can use a Provable.array, but it has to be a fixed size

is there a way to create a stateMap isolated from other users. For example, there will be a stateMap called todo, but this stateMap will be user specific, so each user will have their own todo stateMap.
this way we can keep the merkle root of todo as root against the address in the public todos stateMap

not a part of the framework unfortunately, you can deal with that storage problem same as in other blockchain VMs that only offer one level of key-value storage. By using composite keys such as:
address-todoId : todo

or if you want a multi-token balances module then the storage would be:

balancesKey <> uint64, where balances key: { address, tokenId }

The hash of address and tokenId will be the key, this key will hold the balance:

like StateMap.from(Field, UInt64)?
yep exactly, StateMap.from(BalancesKey, UInt64)
Yep, but you can use structs as keys too
I was getting an error and realized that I forgot to import a type that I used in struct
not sure if this has been answered, but it's simple: the service which calls reduce needs to have the full merkle tree. from that it can create the necessary merkle witnesses for each new leaf
if this process is done in smart contract, can merkle tree be given directly as a parameter?
it can't currently be given directly as a parameter due to non-ideal design of the MerkleTree type
with a bit of extra work it could be passed in
but you could also just load it from some global context

the important point to understand is that `MerkleTree` would not be used anywhere in your actual provable logic. You just use it inside a `Provable.witness()` block to provide merkle witnesses to the circuit
Here is exactly how Unconstrained works
did you mean to ask how it works?
yes
it lets you pass a value to a method / maintain a value in provable code, which is only accessible in witness blocks, i.e. outside the circuit.
check the doccomments: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js-reference/classes/Unconstrained

under the hood, all provable types have two types of content:
* field elements
* "auxiliary data" which is not supposed to be used as part of constraints

most types are just field elements.

an `Unconstrained`, on the other hand, has 0 field elements and is purely auxiliary data
well, here I will calculate the merkle witness returned as a result of witness with its old value and verify that it is equal to the root in the network, right?
yeah, and then compute the new root from the same witness + changed leaf
hmm, got it.
but shouldn't I set this merkle tree here instead of calculating the new value?
not sure what you mean with "set the merkle tree" and "here"

In other words, I need to add the new value to the Merkle tree or MerkleMap that we send as a parameter with the setLeaf or set method so that I can get the other user's witness from the updated tree.
agreed, in your witness block you could get the witness and also set the new leaf while you're there
but you still compute the new root in your provable code
okay I get it thank you
@gregor it also updates the merkleMap I created locally as I updated it in the contract
this is a good thing I don't have to manually add the new values calculated in the contract
the merkleMap I gave as a parameter must be going by reference

I think it can be a problem though because methods are run multiple times, so you mutate your merkle tree multiple times and it's no longer valid. I had to do a workaround for that and clone the entire MerkleTree before passing it to the method

It is executed more than once, yes, but each time it is executed, I think merkleMap enters the method with its initial state because I check the first value of the witness I get from merkleMap in the method and this does not give an error.,

hm ok ok. yeah now I remember that we do clone all method inputs in the method wrapper. so it might just work! 😄 (in my case it was different, I didn't have Unconstrained and so couldn't pass it to the method directly)
Okay 😄
By the way, are you looking for interns for o1labs 😄 ? I have an internship that my university requires me to do.
DMd you 🙂
Protokit is looking for interns too!: D
😄 I can only do the internship in the summer, so I hope your search for interns will continue in the summer
